conclusion: Cylinder height is 2H, total volume is 2V, each chamber volume is V, initial pressure in both chambers is p, initial temperature in both chambers is T, diaphragm mass is m, gravity acts downward, diaphragm rests on a ledge with a gasket providing tight contact.
When the piston moves upward, the gas in the lower chamber expands, decreasing its pressure. The gas in the upper chamber remains at the original pressure p since the diaphragm is fixed on the ledge.
When the pressure difference between chambers exceeds the force per unit area provided by the weight of the diaphragm, the gas will start to leak between chambers.
V_0 is the volume of the lower chamber at the point of leakage, p_0 is the pressure in the lower chamber at the point of leakage.
For leakage to occur, the upward force from the pressure difference must overcome the weight of the diaphragm: (p - p_0) * A = mg.
A is the cross-sectional area of the cylinder.
For the adiabatic expansion in the lower chamber (no heat exchange), we can apply the ideal gas law: pV = nRT (initial state for lower chamber) and p_0V_0 = nRT (state at leakage point).
Since temperature T and amount of gas n remain constant for the lower chamber, p_0V_0 = pV.
Substituting into our leakage condition: (p - pV/V_0) * A = mg.
The cross-sectional area A can be expressed in terms of the initial volume and height: A = V/H.
Introduce the given parameter x = mgH/pV.
